segments.en: Numbered Discourses 4
7. Deeds of Substance
62. Debtlessness

segments.pli: Atha kho anāthapiṇḍiko gahapati yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho anāthapiṇḍikaṃ gahapatiṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
segments.en: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

segments.pli: “Cattārimāni, gahapati, sukhāni adhigamanīyāni gihinā kāmabhoginā kālena kālaṃ samayena samayaṃ upādāya.
segments.en: “Householder, these four kinds of happiness can be earned by a layperson who enjoys sensual pleasures, depending on time and occasion.
What four?
The happiness of ownership, using wealth, debtlessness, and blamelessness.
And what is the happiness of ownership?

segments.pli: Idha, gahapati, kulaputtassa bhogā honti uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatā bāhābalaparicitā sedāvakkhittā dhammikā dhammaladdhā.
segments.en: It’s when a gentleman owns legitimate wealth that he has earned by his own efforts and initiative, built up with his own hands, gathered by the sweat of the brow.

segments.pli: So ‘bhogā me atthi uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatā bāhābalaparicitā sedāvakkhittā dhammikā dhammaladdhā’ti adhigacchati sukhaṃ, adhigacchati somanassaṃ.
segments.en: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.
This is called ‘the happiness of ownership’.
And what is the happiness of using wealth?

segments.pli: Idha, gahapati, kulaputto uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatehi bhogehi bāhābalaparicitehi sedāvakkhittehi dhammikehi dhammaladdhehi paribhuñjati puññāni ca karoti.
segments.en: It’s when a gentleman uses his legitimate wealth, and makes merit with it.

segments.pli: So ‘uṭṭhānavīriyādhigatehi bhogehi bāhābalaparicitehi sedāvakkhittehi dhammikehi dhammaladdhehi paribhuñjāmi puññāni ca karomī’ti adhigacchati sukhaṃ, adhigacchati somanassaṃ.
segments.en: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.
This is called ‘the happiness of using wealth’.
And what is the happiness of debtlessness?

segments.pli: Idha, gahapati, kulaputto na kassaci kiñci dhāreti appaṃ vā bahuṃ vā.
segments.en: It’s when a gentleman owes no debt, large or small, to anyone.

segments.pli: So ‘na kassaci kiñci dhāremi appaṃ vā bahuṃ vā’ti adhigacchati sukhaṃ, adhigacchati somanassaṃ.
segments.en: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.
This is called ‘the happiness of debtlessness’.
And what is the happiness of blamelessness?

segments.pli: Idha, gahapati, ariyasāvako anavajjena kāyakammena samannāgato hoti, anavajjena vacīkammena samannāgato hoti, anavajjena manokammena samannāgato hoti.
segments.en: It’s when a noble disciple has blameless conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

segments.pli: So ‘anavajjenamhi kāyakammena samannāgato, anavajjena vacīkammena samannāgato, anavajjena manokammena samannāgato’ti adhigacchati sukhaṃ, adhigacchati somanassaṃ.
segments.en: When he reflects on this, he’s filled with pleasure and happiness.
This is called ‘the happiness of blamelessness’.

segments.pli: Imāni kho, gahapati, cattāri sukhāni adhigamanīyāni gihinā kāmabhoginā kālena kālaṃ samayena samayaṃ upādāyāti.
segments.en: These four kinds of happiness can be earned by a layperson who enjoys sensual pleasures, depending on time and occasion.
Knowing the happiness of debtlessness,
and the extra happiness of possession,
a mortal enjoying the happiness of using wealth,
then sees clearly with wisdom.
Seeing clearly, a clever person knows
both kinds of happiness:
the other kind is not worth a sixteenth part
of the happiness of blamelessness.”
